{{DEFAULTSORT:Cyprus, Healthcare in}}
[[Category:Health care in Cyprus|Care]]

In the post-[[Soviet Union|Soviet]] era, the quality of [[Uzbekistan]]’s [[health care]] has declined. Between 1992 and 2003, spending on health care and the ratio of hospital beds to population both decreased by nearly 50 percent, and Russian [[emigration]] in that decade deprived the health system of many practitioners. In 2004 Uzbekistan had 53 hospital beds per 10,000 population. Basic medical supplies such as disposable [[Hypodermic needle|needle]]s, [[anesthetics]], and [[antibiotics]] are in very short supply. Although all citizens nominally are entitled to [[free health care]], in the post-Soviet era [[bribery]] has become a common way to bypass the slow and limited service of the state system. In the early 2000s, policy has focused on improving primary health care facilities and cutting the cost of inpatient facilities. The state budget for 2006 allotted 11.1 percent to health expenditures, compared with 10.9 percent in 2005.<ref name=cp>[http://lcweb2.loc.gov/frd/cs/profiles/Uzbekistan.pdf Uzbekistan country profile]. [[Library of Congress]] [[Federal Research Division]] (February 2007). ''This article incorporates text from this source, which is in the [[public domain]].''</ref>
== Health status == Among the most common diseases are those associated with polluted [[drinking water]]: [[typhoid]], [[hepatitis]], [[dysentery]], [[cholera]], and various types of [[cancer]]. The chief causes of death are, in order of frequency, disorders of the cardiovascular, respiratory, and digestive systems and infectious and parasitic diseases. The reported incidence of [[human immunodeficiency virus]] (HIV) has increased sharply beginning in 2002, partly because of a new government reporting policy and partly because of increased [[drug abuse]] In 2005 about 5,600 cases of HIV were known, after 2,000 new cases appeared in 2004. At least two-thirds of cases have been linked with drug abuse. The geographic centers of the HIV cases are [[Tashkent]] and [[Surkhandarya Province]] on the [[Afghanistan]] border. Expanding drug trafficking through Uzbekistan has led to increased drug addiction in urban areas. Some HIV treatment and counseling centers exist. There are 27.4 doctors per 10,000 inhabitants or 2.74 per 1,000 people.<ref name=cp/><ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.nationmaster.com/country-info/stats/Health/Physicians/Per-1,000-people|title=Countries Compared by Health > Physicians > Per 1,000 people. International Statistics at NationMaster.com|website=www.nationmaster.com|access-date=2018-07-25}}</ref>
=== Maternal and child health === The 2010 maternal mortality rate per 100,000 births for Uzbekistan is 30. This is compared with 44.6 in 2008 and 61.1 in 1990. The under 5 mortality rate, per 1,000 births is 38 and the neonatal mortality as a percentage of under 5's mortality is 48. In Uzbekistan the number of midwives per 1,000 live births is unavailable and the lifetime risk of death for pregnant women is 1 in 1400.<ref name="SOWMY">{{cite web|url=http://www.unfpa.org/sowmy/report/home.html|title=The State Of The World's Midwifery|last=|first=|date=2011|website=|publisher=United Nations Population Fund|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|accessdate=}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.unfpa.org/data/sowmy/UZ|title=UNFPA - United Nations Population Fund|website=www.unfpa.org|language=en|access-date=2018-07-25}}</ref>
== External links == *[http://www.unfpa.org/sowmy/resources/docs/country_info/profile/en_Uzbekistan_SoWMy_Profile.pdf The State of The World's Midwifery - Uzbekistan Country Profile]
==References== {{reflist}} {{Asia topic|Health in}} [[Category:Health in Uzbekistan| ]]

{{Expert needed|Uganda|talk=|reason= unclear use of titles for Ugandan royalty|date=February 2015}} {{Infobox royalty | name = Princess Mpologoma | image = <!-- just the filename, without the File: or Image: prefix or enclosing [[brackets]] --> | alt = | caption = | birth_name = Jane Mpologoma Nabanakulya | birth_date = {{Birth date and age|1964|04|12}} | birth_place = Sunga Village, Buyaga County, Bunyoro-Kitara Kingdom | death_date = <!-- {{Death date and age|YYYY|MM|DD|YYYY|MM|DD}} or {{Death-date and age|death date†|birth date†}} --> | death_place = | nationality = | other_names = | occupation = Nurse, pastor | father = [[Mutesa II of Buganda]] | mother = Naome Nanyonga | spouse = David Segawa Mukasa | years_active = | known_for = | notable_works = }} '''Princess Jane Mpologoma Nabanakulya''' is a daughter of Uganda's first President [[Mutesa II of Buganda]].<ref>{{citation|periodical=All Africa(Uganda Observer)|title=Uganda:|date=June 6, 2013 |accessdate=April 18, 2014 |url=http://allafrica.com/stories/201306070317.html}}</ref> She was born in Sunga Village, Buyaga County, [[Bunyoro|Bunyoro-Kitara Kingdom]], on April 12, 1964 by Omuzaana Naome Nanyonga, a midwife of Major General Sir [[Mutesa II of Buganda]].
==Early life== Princess Mpologoma grew up with her mother throughout her childhood and she never saw her father,<ref>{{citation|title=How a Ugandan Princess was able to forgive the killers of her father, ’King Freddie’ of Buganda |periodical=Assist News Service |date=October 12, 2011 |accessdate=April 18, 2014 |url=http://www.assistnews.net/Stories/2011/s11100047.htm |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20111122160722/http://www.assistnews.net/Stories/2011/s11100047.htm |archivedate=November 22, 2011 |df= }}</ref> although she was regularly visited by Prince Juuko Walugembe of Bugerere. She was also taken care of by Arafayiri Musoke, a well known farmer in Sunga and an old friend of the late [[Kabaka of Buganda]].
==Education== Princess Mopologoma attended Aga Khan Primary School in [[Kampala]] and later on she joined ''Ngora Nursing School'' in [[Ngora]], [[Teso sub-region]], in [[Eastern Region, Uganda|Eastern Uganda]]. She relocated to [[Athens]], [[Greece]], where she continued her studies in nursing. Later, she moved to [[Stockholm]], [[Sweden]]. In 2003 she moved to [[London]], [[United Kingdom]], where she lives with her husband, Duke David Segawa Mukasa.<ref>{{citation|title=Christian Telegraph|periodical=http://www.christiantelegraph.com/issue18217.html}}</ref> They are now co-pastors a Manmin Church in Bethnal Green, London.
==References== {{reflist|2}}

[[Province of Alessandria]] ([[Piedmont]]) | coords = {{coord|44|33|2|N|8|49|18|E|region:IT_source:dewiki_type:waterbody|display=inline,title}} | type = | inflow = [[Gorzente]] | outflow = Rio Lischeo | catchment = | basin_countries = Italy | length = | width = | area = | depth = | max-depth = | volume = | residence_time = | shore = | elevation = | frozen = | islands = | cities = | reference = }} '''Laghi del Gorzente''' is a group of three [[lake]]s in north-west [[Italy]] which straddles the provinces of [[Province of Genoa|Genoa]] (in [[Liguria]]) and [[Province of Alessandria|Alessandria]] (in [[Piedmont]]). == Geography == The lowest lake is named ''Lago Bruno'' (647 m), while ''Lago Lungo'' is at 684 m and ''Lago Badana'' at 717 m.Istituto Geografico Centrale - Carta dei sentieri 1:50.000 n. 16 ''Genova - Varazze -Ovada'' == Nature conservation == The lakes are included in the Piedmontese natural park of the ''[[Parco naturale delle Capanne di Marcarolo|Capanne di Marcarolo]]''.{{Cite web | title = I confini del parco |publisher = Ente di gestione delle Aree protette Appennino piemontese |url = http://www.areeprotetteappenninopiemontese.it/index.php?option=com_content&view=article&id=287&Itemid=132 | website = www.areeprotetteappenninopiemontese.it | access-date = 2016-04-07}} == References == {{Reflist}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Gorzente}} [[Category:Reservoirs in Italy]] [[Category:Lakes of Liguria]] [[Category:Lakes of Piedmont]] [[Category:Metropolitan City of Genoa]] [[Category:Province of Alessandria]] {{-}} {{Liguria-geo-stub}} {{Piedmont-geo-stub}}

revision.text:
{{Infobox criminal |image_name = |name =Lindsay Sandiford |image_size = |image_caption = |birth_name =Lindsay June Sandiford |birth_date = {{Birth date and age|df=yes|1956|6|25}}<ref name="´Reprieve.org">{{cite news|first= |last= |url=http://www.reprieve.org.uk/cases/Lindsay_Sandiford_Indonesia/ |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20121201094852/http://www.reprieve.org.uk/cases/Lindsay_Sandiford_Indonesia/ |dead-url=yes |archive-date=1 December 2012 |title= Lindsay Sandiford is a British grandmother sentenced to death in Bali, Indonesia.|publisher=Reprieve |date=23 January 2013 |accessdate=23 January 2013}}</ref> |birth_place = [[United Kingdom]] |death_date = |death_place = |alias = |conviction = Drug trafficking |conviction_penalty = [[Capital punishment|Death]] by [[Execution by firing squad|firing squad]] |conviction_status = Incarcerated on [[death row]] at [[Kerobokan Prison]] |occupation = Legal secretary |spouse = |parents = |children = 2 }}
'''Lindsay June Sandiford''' (born 25 June 1956) is a former legal secretary and convicted drug smuggler from [[Redcar]], [[Teesside]] in [[North Yorkshire]], [[England]] who was [[Capital punishment in Indonesia|sentenced to death]] in January 2013 by a court in [[Indonesia]] after being found guilty of smuggling [[cocaine]] into [[Bali]]. Although death is the maximum punishment for drugs-related offences under Indonesian law, the severity of the sentence was greeted with shock because prosecutors had not recommended the death penalty for Sandiford. The ruling was also condemned by the [[Government of the United Kingdom|British government]] and anti–death penalty campaigners.
Sandiford was arrested on 19 May 2012 after arriving at the island's [[Ngurah Rai International Airport]] on a flight from [[Bangkok]] when a routine luggage search uncovered the drugs stash. Under subsequent police interrogation she claimed to have been coerced into carrying the drugs by a criminal gang that had made threats against her family, and took part in a [[sting operation]] to arrest several other individuals she alleged to be part of a drugs trafficking ring.
In December 2012, she was convicted of drug smuggling at Denpasar District Court and sentenced to [[Execution by firing squad|death by firing squad]] in January 2013. By contrast, the others involved in the case were convicted of lesser drugs-related offences and received custodial sentences. Prosecutors had recommended Sandiford should also receive a custodial sentence because of her willingness to cooperate with police, but the panel of judges overseeing the hearing felt her actions had undermined Indonesia's anti-drugs policy and concluded there were no mitigating circumstances in her favour.
Sandiford subsequently launched an appeal against the court's decision. She had funded her own defence costs during the initial trial but had no money for representation at appeal. Funds were subsequently raised to pay for an appeal lawyer, and the appeals procedure began. In the United Kingdom lawyers applied to seek a judicial review of the government's stance of not providing financial aid for Britons facing criminal proceedings overseas, but their legal challenge was dismissed by judges at the [[High Court of England and Wales]] on the grounds that Sandiford had little chance in successfully appealing the sentence. An appeal arguing the government's position was unlawful was also rejected. The British government submitted a statement to the Court in Bali alleging unlawful behaviour towards Sandiford by officials at the time of her arrest. The High Court in Bali rejected the first stage of Sandiford's appeal in April 2013, upholding the death sentence. An appeal was subsequently lodged with the country's Supreme Court, but in August this was also rejected.
==Background and arrest== [[File:Denpasar Airport 200507-2.jpg|thumb|right|[[Ngurah Rai International Airport]], where Sandiford was arrested after arriving from Bangkok.]]
Sandiford was raised in the north-eastern town of Redcar, Teesside in [[North Yorkshire]], before moving to London. She later lived in [[Cheltenham]], [[Gloucestershire]].<ref name=Daily-Mail-2013-01-22a/> A former [[legal secretary]], she worked for many years in management at the Cheltenham-based law firm DTS Legal.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.thisisgloucestershire.co.uk/Death-sentence-Cheltenham-grandmother-Lindsay/story-17937172-detail/story.html |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20130125010301/http://www.thisisgloucestershire.co.uk/Death-sentence-Cheltenham-grandmother-Lindsay/story-17937172-detail/story.html |dead-url=yes |archive-date=25 January 2013 |title=Death sentence for Cheltenham grandmother Lindsay Sandiford, guilty drug trafficking |publisher=Northcliffe Media |newspaper=Gloucestershire Echo |date=23 January 2013 |accessdate=29 January 2013 |df= }}</ref><ref>{{cite news|first=Alex |last=Spillius |first2=Tom |last2=Whitehead |first3=Jonathan |last3=Pearlman |url=http://www.independent.ie/world-news/asia-pacific/grandmother-faces-death-by-firing-squad-over-drugs-3362624.html |title=Grandmother faces death by firing squad over drugs |publisher=Independent News and Media |newspaper=Irish Independent |date=23 January 2013 |accessdate=29 January 2013}}</ref> She rented a house in the town, but was evicted after failing to pay her rent, and in early 2012 moved to live in India. Sandiford was married but separated, the relationship having produced two children.<ref name=Daily-Mail-2013-01-22a/>
Sandiford was arrested on 19 May 2012 after arriving at [[Bali]]'s [[Ngurah Rai International Airport]] on a [[Thai Airways]] flight from [[Bangkok]], Thailand, when 4.8 kg (10.6 lb) of cocaine was found in the lining of her suitcase during a routine search.<ref name=Channel4News-2012-05-29>{{cite news |url=http://www.channel4.com/news/briton-faces-death-penalty-over-drugs-smuggling |title=Briton faces death penalty over Bali drugs 'smuggling' |work=Channel 4 News |publisher=ITN |date=29 May 2012 |accessdate=23 January 2013 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130126063107/http://www.channel4.com/news/briton-faces-death-penalty-over-drugs-smuggling |archivedate=26 January 2013 |df= }}</ref> She claimed to have been forced into carrying the drugs by a gang who had threatened to harm members of her family if she did not comply with their demands.<ref name=Channel4News-2012-05-29/> When informed she could receive the death penalty for drug trafficking she broke down and told police that she had been asked to carry the drugs for Julian Ponder, a British antiques dealer living in Bali, and his partner Rachel Dougall, and agreed to help in a sting operation to arrest them.<ref name=Daily-Mail-2013-01-22/> Sandiford was booked into a hotel with an undercover police officer, where she went about contacting members of the alleged syndicate. Arrangements were made for her to meet Ponder, and another man, Paul Beales at the hotel, where police arrested them on suspicion of drug trafficking.<ref name=Daily-Mail-2013-01-22/> Dougall was arrested after a subsequent search of the property she shared with Ponder uncovered 48.94 grammes of cocaine, while 3.1 grammes of [[hashish]] were found at Beale's house. Sandiford and Ponder were charged with drug trafficking.<ref>{{cite news |last=Eimer |first=David |url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/worldnews/asia/indonesia/9593869/Last-of-four-Brits-in-Bali-court-on-drug-charges.html |title=Last of four Brits in Bali court on drug charges |publisher=Telegraph Media Group |newspaper=The Daily Telegraph |date=8 October 2012 |accessdate=23 January 2013 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20121011030107/http://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/worldnews/asia/indonesia/9593869/Last-of-four-Brits-in-Bali-court-on-drug-charges.html |archivedate=11 October 2012 |df= }}</ref> However, police failed to find evidence linking the other two to the crime, and they were charged with less serious offences.<ref name=Daily-Mail-2013-01-22/>
==Trial and conviction== At her trial prosecutors alleged that Sandiford met Dougall and Beales at a hotel in Bangkok on 17 May 2012, where arrangements were made for her to courier the cocaine into Bali. She arrived on the island two days later.<ref name=Daily-Mail-2013-01-22>{{cite news |first=Martin |last=Robinson |url=http://www.dailymail.co.uk/news/article-2266463/Lindsay-Sandiford-A-drug-smuggler-suburbia-King-Queen-Bali-plot-import-1-6m-cocaine.html |title=Lindsay Sandiford: A drug smuggler from suburbia, the 'King and Queen of Bali' and the plot to import £1.6m of cocaine |newspaper=Daily Mail |publisher=Daily Mail and General Trust |date=22 January 2013 |accessdate=23 January 2013 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://archive.is/20130420012720/http://www.dailymail.co.uk/news/article-2266463/Lindsay-Sandiford-A-drug-smuggler-suburbia-King-Queen-Bali-plot-import-1-6m-cocaine.html |archivedate=20 April 2013 |df= }}</ref> In her defence, Sandiford claimed that she had been pressured into carrying the drugs by a gang who had made threats against her children, while her lawyers argued she was suffering from mental health problems.<ref name=BBC-2013-01-22a/> In a statement to the court she expressed regret over her involvement, "I would like to begin by apologising to the Republic of Indonesia and the Indonesian people for my involvement. I would never have become involved in something like this but the lives of my children were in danger and I felt I had to protect them."<ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.channel4.com/news/british-woman-sentenced-to-death-in-bali |title=Government condemns Sandiford death penalty |work=Channel 4 News |publisher=ITN |date=22 January 2013 |accessdate=23 January 2013 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130124153644/http://www.channel4.com/news/british-woman-sentenced-to-death-in-bali |archivedate=24 January 2013 |df= }}</ref> Her son gave a statement to the court in which he said he believed she was forced to carry the drugs following a disagreement over rent money she had paid on his behalf.<ref name=BBC-2013-01-22a/> A report by Dr. Jennifer Fleetwood, a lecturer in criminology at the [[University of Kent]] and expert on women in the international drugs trade was also presented to the court, suggesting Sandiford was an ideal target for drug traffickers. "There is … evidence to suggest that a trafficker would seek someone who was vulnerable. Having reviewed extracts from Lindsay's medical records I know that Lindsay has a history of mental health issues … This may have unfortunately made her an attractive target for threats, manipulation and coercion."<ref name=Daily-Mail-2013-01-22a/><ref name=Guardian-2013-01-22/>
Sandiford was convicted on 19 December, with a recommendation from prosecutors that she be spared the death penalty – the maximum punishment for drug trafficking under Indonesian law – because of her age and cooperation with police, and instead receive a 15-year custodial sentence. On the same day, Rachel Dougall was found guilty of failing to report a crime, while Paul Beales was convicted of possessing hashish.<ref>{{cite news |last=Eimer |first=David |url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/worldnews/asia/indonesia/9758850/British-grandmother-faces-15-years-in-Bali-jail-for-drug-smuggling.html |title=British grandmother faces 15 years in Bali jail for drug smuggling |publisher=Telegraph Media Group |newspaper=The Daily Telegraph |date=20 December 2012 |accessdate=23 January 2013 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20121223092448/http://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/worldnews/asia/indonesia/9758850/British-grandmother-faces-15-years-in-Bali-jail-for-drug-smuggling.html |archivedate=23 December 2012 |df= }}</ref> They later received one year and four-year prison sentences respectively.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.adelaidenow.com.au/british-grandmother-lindsay-sandiford-may-appeal-bali-death-sentence/story-e6frea6u-1226559748961 |title=British grandmother Lindsay Sandiford may appeal Bali death sentence |publisher=News Limited |newspaper=The Advertiser |date=23 January 2013|accessdate=23 January 2013}}</ref> Julian Ponder was cleared of drug smuggling, but convicted of the possession of narcotics in January 2013, and sentenced to six years' imprisonment.<ref name=BBC-2013-01-29>{{cite news |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-21240673 |work=BBC News |title=Julian Ponder jailed for six years for Bali drug possession |publisher=BBC |date=29 January 2013 |accessdate=29 January 2013 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130129020144/http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-21240673 |archivedate=29 January 2013 |df= }}</ref>
==Sentencing== [[File:KerobokanPrison.jpg|thumb|left|Sandiford was held at [[Kerobokan Prison]] following her sentence.]]
Despite the prosecution's recommendation of leniency, at her sentencing hearing on 22 January 2013 a panel of judges ruled there were no mitigating circumstances in Sandiford's favour, and imposed a death sentence.<ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-21137649 |work=BBC News |title=Bali drugs: Death sentence for Briton Lindsay Sandiford |publisher=BBC |date=22 January 2013 |accessdate=22 January 2013 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130122184154/http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-21137649 |archivedate=22 January 2013 |df= }}</ref><ref>{{cite news |first=Andrew |last=Buncombe |url=https://www.independent.co.uk/news/world/asia/british-grandmother-lindsay-sandiford-weeps-as-she-is-sentenced-to-death-by-indonesian-court-for-drug-trafficking-8461071.html |title=British grandmother Lindsay Sandiford weeps as she is sentenced to death by Indonesian court for drug trafficking |publisher=Independent Print Ltd |newspaper=The Independent |date=22 January 2013 |accessdate=22 January 2013 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130123163503/http://www.independent.co.uk/news/world/asia/british-grandmother-lindsay-sandiford-weeps-as-she-is-sentenced-to-death-by-indonesian-court-for-drug-trafficking-8461071.html |archivedate=23 January 2013 |df= }}</ref> Amser Simanjuntak, who headed the panel said Sandiford's actions had damaged Bali's reputation as a tourist destination and undermined Indonesia's fight against drugs, while his colleague, Komang Wijaya Adi said their decision had been influenced by several factors, including what was viewed as her lack of remorse.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.thejakartapost.com/news/2013/01/23/death-sentence-surprises-defendant.html |title=Death sentence surprises defendant |publisher=PT Bina Media Tenggara |newspaper=The Jakarta Post |date=23 January 2013 |accessdate=23 January 2013 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130125231624/http://www.thejakartapost.com/news/2013/01/23/death-sentence-surprises-defendant.html |archivedate=25 January 2013 |df= }}</ref><ref>{{cite news |first=Richard |last=Smith |first2= |last2=Rossington |url=https://www.mirror.co.uk/news/world-news/lindsay-sandiford-sentenced-to-death-in-indonesia-1548903 |title=Lindsay Sandiford sentenced to death in Indonesia for smuggling £1.6million of cocaine |newspaper=Daily Mirror |publisher=Trinity Mirror |date=22 January 2013 |accessdate=24 January 2013 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130124101508/http://www.mirror.co.uk/news/world-news/lindsay-sandiford-sentenced-to-death-in-indonesia-1548903 |archivedate=24 January 2013 |df= }}</ref> The sentence was greeted with gasps from around the courtroom.<ref name=Daily-Mail-2013-01-22a/> In Indonesia an execution is generally carried out by firing squad, often at night in an isolated location.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.heraldsun.com.au/news/british-woman-gets-bali-death-sentence-over-cocaine-smuggling/story-e6frf7jo-1226559509016 |title=British grandma gets Bali death sentence over cocaine smuggling |newspaper=Herald Sun |publisher=The Herald and Weekly Times |date=23 January 2013 |accessdate=24 January 2013}}</ref> Following the judgment Sandiford was led from the court in a distressed state, where she declined to speak to journalists before being escorted away by guards to be held at Bali's notorious [[Kerobokan Prison]].<ref name=Daily-Mail-2013-01-22a/><ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.ibtimes.com/lindsay-june-sandiford-sentenced-death-indonesian-court-after-smuggling-25-million-worth-cocaine |title=Lindsay June Sandiford Sentenced To Death By Indonesian Court After Smuggling $2.5 Million Worth Of Cocaine Into Bali |publisher=Etienne Uzac |newspaper=International Business Times |date=22 January 2013 |accessdate=23 January 2013 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130127011332/http://www.ibtimes.com/lindsay-june-sandiford-sentenced-death-indonesian-court-after-smuggling-25-million-worth-cocaine |archivedate=27 January 2013 |df= }}</ref> Her lawyers announced she would appeal, a process that can take several years under Indonesian law.<ref name=Sky-News-2013-01-22>{{cite news |url=http://news.sky.com/story/1041142/bali-death-penalty-for-british-drug-smuggler |title=Bali: Death Penalty For British Drug Smuggler |publisher=British Sky Broadcasting |work=Sky News |date=22 January 2013 |accessdate=23 January 2013 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130123100059/http://news.sky.com/story/1041142/bali-death-penalty-for-british-drug-smuggler |archivedate=23 January 2013 |df= }}</ref><ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.ft.com/cms/s/0/ae8d5054-64ae-11e2-ac53-00144feab49a.html#axzz2Iu5Opfte |title=UK woman sentenced to death in Indonesia |publisher=Pearson PLC |newspaper=Financial Times |date=22 January 2013 |accessdate=24 January 2013}}</ref>
In response to the sentence the British embassy in Indonesia said the United Kingdom "remains strongly opposed to the death penalty in all circumstances" and that it was in touch with the UK government to discuss how best to provide Sandiford with legal representation.<ref>{{cite news|last=Lisnawati |first=Firdia |url=http://www.montrealgazette.com/news/world/Indonesian+court+sentences+British+woman+death+over+drug/7852197/story.html |archive-url=https://archive.is/20130216114152/http://www.montrealgazette.com/news/world/Indonesian+court+sentences+British+woman+death+over+drug/7852197/story.html |dead-url=yes |archive-date=16 February 2013 |title=Indonesian court sentences 56-year-old British woman to death over drug smuggling to Bali |publisher= Postmedia Network|newspaper=Montreal Gazette |date=22 January 2013 |accessdate=22 January 2013}}</ref> In a statement to the [[House of Commons (United Kingdom)|House of Commons]], [[Hugo Swire]], Minister of State for the [[Foreign and Commonwealth Office|Foreign Office]] expressed his concern about the decision. "We are aware that Lindsay Sandiford is facing the death penalty in Indonesia. We strongly object to the death penalty and continue to provide consular assistance to Lindsay and her family during this difficult time." He also said that [[Secretary of State for Foreign and Commonwealth Affairs|Foreign Secretary]] [[William Hague]] had raised the matter with his Indonesian counterpart.<ref>{{cite news |first=Jonathan |last=Pearlman |url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/worldnews/asia/indonesia/9818499/Lindsay-Sandiford-execution-cruel-in-the-extreme.html |title=Lindsay Sandiford execution 'cruel in the extreme' |publisher=Telegraph Media Group |newspaper=The Daily Telegraph |date=22 January 2013 |accessdate=23 January 2013 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130123202654/http://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/worldnews/asia/indonesia/9818499/Lindsay-Sandiford-execution-cruel-in-the-extreme.html |archivedate=23 January 2013 |df= }}</ref>
[[Martin Horwood]], MP for [[Cheltenham (UK Parliament constituency)|Cheltenham]], Sandiford's most recent UK residence, expressed his shock at the sentence. "The days of the death penalty ought to be past. This is not the way that a country that now values democracy and human rights should really be behaving."<ref name=Guardian-2013-01-22>{{cite news |first=Alexandra |last=Topping |url=https://www.theguardian.com/world/2013/jan/22/indonesia-sentences-briton-death-drugs |title=Briton Lindsay Sandiford sentenced to death in Indonesia for drug trafficking |publisher=Guardian Media Group |newspaper=The Guardian |date=22 January 2013 |accessdate=24 January 2013 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160506174154/http://www.theguardian.com/world/2013/jan/22/indonesia-sentences-briton-death-drugs |archivedate=6 May 2016 |df= }}</ref> The sentence was also condemned by the anti–death penalty charity [[Reprieve (organisation)|Reprieve]], which has taken up her case. The organisation's Harriet McCulloch said, "She is clearly not a drug king pin - she has no money to pay for a lawyer, for the travel costs of defence witnesses or even for essentials like food and water. She has cooperated fully with the Indonesian authorities but has been sentenced to death while the gang operating in the UK, Thailand and Indonesia remain free to target other vulnerable people."<ref name=BBC-2013-01-22a>{{cite news |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-21149631 |work=BBC News |title=Bali drugs: Lindsay Sandiford death sentence criticised |publisher=BBC |date=22 January 2013 |accessdate=23 January 2013 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130122184633/http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-21149631 |archivedate=22 January 2013 |df= }}</ref> Tim Hancock, Campaigns Director of [[Amnesty International UK]] also criticised the sentence. "It is extremely sad to hear that judges have decided to give Lindsay Sandiford a death sentence – despite the fact that the prosecution weren't even asking for it. She is the second British citizen sentenced to death for drug offences in the last six months – an extremely worrying trend."<ref name=Daily-Mail-2013-01-22a>{{cite news |first=Martin |last=Robinson |first2=Richard |last2=Shears |url=http://www.dailymail.co.uk/news/article-2266264/Lindsay-Sandiford-Bali-drug-smuggling-British-grandmother-breaks-Indonesian-court-sentences-death.html |title=Can drug-smuggling grandmother escape the Bali firing squad? British woman faces years in overcrowded prison as lawyers fight to change her death sentence |publisher=Daily Mail and General Trust |newspaper=Daily Mail |date=23 January 2013 |accessdate=24 January 2013 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://archive.is/20130422041421/http://www.dailymail.co.uk/news/article-2266264/Lindsay-Sandiford-Bali-drug-smuggling-British-grandmother-breaks-Indonesian-court-sentences-death.html |archivedate=22 April 2013 |df= }}</ref>{{efn|Another British citizen, Gareth Cashmore, had been sentenced to death by Indonesia for drugs offences in October 2012.<ref name=Daily-Mail-2013-01-22a/>}}
At the time Sandiford was sentenced to death no executions had been carried out by Indonesia since 2008. On 4 February 2013 the country's attorney general, [[Basrief Arief]], signalled his intention to resume executions by shortening the length of the appeals process, which he believed had delayed them.<ref>{{cite news |first=John |last=Hall |url=https://www.independent.co.uk/news/world/asia/british-grandmother-lindsay-sandiford-caught-smuggling-cocaine-in-bali-could-be-executed-within-weeks-8479399.html |title=British grandmother Lindsay Sandiford caught smuggling cocaine in Bali 'could be executed within weeks' |publisher=Independent Print Ltd |newspaper=The Independent |date=4 February 2013 |accessdate=4 February 2013 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130206233507/http://www.independent.co.uk/news/world/asia/british-grandmother-lindsay-sandiford-caught-smuggling-cocaine-in-bali-could-be-executed-within-weeks-8479399.html |archivedate=6 February 2013 |df= }}</ref> The country resumed executing condemned prisoners on 15 March, when a Malawian drug trafficker, Adami Wilson, was executed by firing squad in the early hours of the morning.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.timesofoman.com/News/Article-10999.aspx |title=Indonesia resumes executions after hiatus |publisher=Muscat Press and Publishing House |newspaper=Times of Oman |date=15 March 2013 |accessdate=18 March 2013 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130318175415/http://www.timesofoman.com/News/Article-10999.aspx |archivedate=18 March 2013 |df= }}</ref><ref>{{cite news |first=Josh |last=Whittington |url=http://www.theaustralian.com.au/news/indonesia-resumes-executions-after-hiatus/story-e6frg6n6-1226598668972 |title=Indonesia resumes executions after hiatus, adding to fears for Bali Nine members |publisher=News Limited |newspaper=The Australian |date=16 March 2013 |accessdate=20 March 2013 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150211165101/http://www.theaustralian.com.au/news/indonesia-resumes-executions-after-hiatus/story-e6frg6n6-1226598668972 |archivedate=11 February 2015 |df= }}</ref> On 12 April Amser Simanjuntak, the judge who sentenced Sandiford to death, was found dead at his home, having suffered a fatal heart attack.<ref>{{cite news |first=Richard |last=Shears |url=http://www.dailymail.co.uk/news/article-2309371/Lindsay-Sandiford-judge-dies-heart-attack-revealed-reputation-harsh-sentences.html |title=Lindsay Sandiford judge dies of heart attack as it is revealed he had reputation for harsh sentences |newspaper=Daily Mail |publisher=Daily Mail and General Trust |date=15 April 2013 |accessdate=15 April 2013 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://archive.is/20130504230247/http://www.dailymail.co.uk/news/article-2309371/Lindsay-Sandiford-judge-dies-heart-attack-revealed-reputation-harsh-sentences.html |archivedate=4 May 2013 |df= }}. Dailymail.co.uk. Retrieved on 2013-04-15.</ref>
==Appeal== Sandiford had seven days to lodge an appeal following the sentence.<ref name=BBC-2013-01-28/> An initial letter of appeal drafted by diplomats was rejected by court officials because guidelines require an appeal to be filed from the prison.<ref>{{cite news |first=Simon |last=Parry |url=http://www.dailymail.co.uk/news/article-2272515/Lindsay-Sandiford-Firing-squad-granny-race-time-appeal-blunder-Foreign-Office.html#axzz2Jn0MbScI |title=Lindsay Sandiford: Firing squad granny in race against time to appeal after blunder by the Foreign Office |newspaper=Daily Mail |publisher=Daily Mail and General Trust |date=3 February 2013 |accessdate=4 February 2013 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://archive.is/20130420115333/http://www.dailymail.co.uk/news/article-2272515/Lindsay-Sandiford-Firing-squad-granny-race-time-appeal-blunder-Foreign-Office.html%23axzz2Jn0MbScI#axzz2Jn0MbScI |archivedate=4 February 2013 |df= }}</ref> On 28 January Gede Ketut Rantam, registrar of Denpasar District Court in Bali confirmed his office had received an appeal request from Sandiford.<ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/worldnews/asia/indonesia/9831152/British-grandmother-appeals-Bali-drugs-death-sentence.html |title=British grandmother appeals Bali drugs death sentence |publisher=Telegraph Media Group |newspaper=The Daily Telegraph |date=28 January 2013 |accessdate=28 January 2013 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130129223513/http://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/worldnews/asia/indonesia/9831152/British-grandmother-appeals-Bali-drugs-death-sentence.html |archivedate=29 January 2013 |df= }}</ref> She was then given a further fourteen days to file a more detailed appeal.<ref name=Guardian-2013-01-31/> The appellate system of Indonesia has three levels; the High Court, the [[Supreme Court of Indonesia|Supreme Court]], and a direct appeal for clemency to the [[President of Indonesia|President]].<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.thisisgloucestershire.co.uk/Lindsay-Sandiford-awaits-execution-ask-death/story-18057828-detail/story.html |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20130208034200/http://www.thisisgloucestershire.co.uk/Lindsay-Sandiford-awaits-execution-ask-death/story-18057828-detail/story.html |dead-url=yes |archive-date= 8 February 2013 |title=Lindsay Sandiford Bali death sentence debate |publisher=Northcliffe Media |newspaper=Gloucestershire Echo |date=5 February 2013 |accessdate=5 February 2013 |df= }}</ref>{{efn|As of April 2013 the incumbent President [[Susilo Bambang Yudhoyono]] had commuted four death sentences since taking office in 2004.<ref name=Guardian-2013-04-08>{{cite news |first=Alexandra |last=Topping |url=https://www.theguardian.com/world/2013/apr/08/bali-upholds-death-sentence-lindsay-sandiford |title=Lindsay Sandiford: Bali court upholds death sentence for smuggling cocaine |publisher=Guardian Media Group |newspaper=The Guardian |date=8 April 2013 |accessdate=10 April 2013 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130910213523/http://www.theguardian.com/world/2013/apr/08/bali-upholds-death-sentence-lindsay-sandiford |archivedate=10 September 2013 |df= }}</ref>}}
Her financial resources had been exhausted by legal costs during her trial, and consular staff identified an Indonesian lawyer who was willing to represent her on a [[pro bono]] basis at appeal, but who required expenses of £2,500 to travel to Bali.<ref name=Guardian-2013-01-31>{{cite news |first=Owen |last=Bowcott |url=https://www.theguardian.com/law/2013/jan/31/lindsay-sandiford-uk-bali-drugs |title=Bali drugs: UK government accused of breaching Lindsay Sandiford's rights |publisher=Guardian Media Group |newspaper=The Guardian |date=31 January 2013 |accessdate=31 January 2013 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160313101639/http://www.theguardian.com/law/2013/jan/31/lindsay-sandiford-uk-bali-drugs |archivedate=13 March 2016 |df= }}</ref> On 1 February Teesside's ''[[Evening Gazette (Teesside)|Evening Gazette]]'' reported that £3,500 had been collectively pledged by donors to accounts established on online donation sites [[Justgiving]] and [[Indiegogo]] to pay for her legal fees.<ref>{{cite news |first=Dave |last=Robson |url=http://www.gazettelive.co.uk/news/teesside-news/2013/02/01/donations-flood-in-as-teessider-lindsay-sandiford-fights-drugs-death-sentence-84229-32724935/ |title=Donations flood in as Teessider Lindsay Sandiford fights drugs death sentence |publisher=Trinity Mirror |newspaper=Evening Gazette |date=1 February 2013 |accessdate=1 February 2013 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130202190814/http://www.gazettelive.co.uk/news/teesside-news/2013/02/01/donations-flood-in-as-teessider-lindsay-sandiford-fights-drugs-death-sentence-84229-32724935/ |archivedate=2 February 2013 |df= }}</ref> On 4 February the ''Gazette'' reported that the money had been used to hire a lawyer, while a Reprieve official was working in Bali to help file the appeal.<ref>{{cite news |first=Sandy |last=McKenzie |url=http://www.gazettelive.co.uk/news/teesside-news/2013/02/04/appeal-cash-is-raised-for-lindsay-sandiford-84229-32741893/ |title=Appeal cash is raised for Lindsay Sandiford |publisher=Trinity Mirror |newspaper=Evening Gazette |date=4 February 2013 |accessdate=4 February 2013 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://archive.is/20130420074034/http://www.gazettelive.co.uk/news/teesside-news/2013/02/04/appeal-cash-is-raised-for-lindsay-sandiford-84229-32741893/ |archivedate=20 April 2013 |df= }}</ref> Sandiford's lawyer, Fadillah Agus, lodged an appeal with the Indonesian High Court on 11 February.<ref name=Telegraph-2013-02-11>{{cite news |url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/worldnews/asia/indonesia/9861910/British-grandmother-Lindsay-Sandiford-appeals-Indonesia-death-sentence.html |title=British grandmother Lindsay Sandiford appeals Indonesia death sentence |publisher=Telegraph Media Group |newspaper=The Daily Telegraph |date=11 February 2013 |accessdate=12 February 2013 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130212074717/http://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/worldnews/asia/indonesia/9861910/British-grandmother-Lindsay-Sandiford-appeals-Indonesia-death-sentence.html |archivedate=12 February 2013 |df= }}</ref> He argued that Sandiford's sentence did not take into account her cooperation with police.<ref>{{cite news |first=Jonathan |last=Samuels |url=http://news.sky.com/story/1050975/bali-lindsay-sandiford-fights-death-penalty |title=Bali: Lindsay Sandiford Fights Death Penalty |publisher=British Sky Broadcasting |work=Sky News |date=12 February 2013 |accessdate=12 February 2013 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130215014659/http://news.sky.com/story/1050975/bali-lindsay-sandiford-fights-death-penalty |archivedate=15 February 2013 |df= }}</ref>
In February 2013 the Foreign and Commonwealth Office submitted an ''[[amicus curiae]]''{{efn|The [[Latin]] phrase ''amicus curiae'', which translates as "friend of the court", is a statement submitted to a court by a party who offers unsolicited information in a case.<ref name=Independent-2013-02-13/>}} to Denpasar District Court alleging that police had used [[sleep deprivation]] on Sandiford and threatened her with a firearm following her arrest, and consequently "violated Lindsay Sandiford's fundamental rights under international laws and the Indonesian constitution".<ref name=Independent-2013-02-13/><ref>{{cite news|url= http://www.dailymail.co.uk/news/article-2305171/William-Hague-urges-Indonesia-execute-British-grandmother-convicted-drug-smuggling.html|title= William Hague asks Indonesia to spare British grandmother convicted of drug smuggling from death penalty|first= Simon|last= Parry|newspaper= Daily Mail|publisher= Daily Mail and General Trust|date= 6 April 2013|accessdate= 7 April 2013|deadurl= no|archiveurl= https://archive.is/20130504231728/http://www.dailymail.co.uk/news/article-2305171/William-Hague-urges-Indonesia-execute-British-grandmother-convicted-drug-smuggling.html|archivedate= 4 May 2013|df= }}</ref> The document also argued her punishment was disproportionate to the crime she committed, and did not take into account her cooperation with authorities.<ref name=Independent-2013-02-13>{{cite news |url=http://www.iol.co.za/news/world/uk-intervenes-in-bali-death-row-case-1.1469756#.UR0QN2hRtAE |title=UK intervenes in Bali death row case |publisher=Independent News and Media |work=Independent Online: South Africa |date=13 February 2013 |accessdate=14 February 2013 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130904233659/http://www.iol.co.za/news/world/uk-intervenes-in-bali-death-row-case-1.1469756#.UR0QN2hRtAE |archivedate=4 September 2013 |df= }}</ref> The British consulate in Bali also submitted a statement to the court expressing the country's objection to the death penalty.<ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-21479297 |work=BBC News |title=Bali drugs: UK officials add statement to Sandiford appeal |publisher=BBC |date=15 February 2013 |accessdate=15 February 2013 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130215203556/http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-21479297 |archivedate=15 February 2013 |df= }}</ref>
Bali's High Court announced on 8 April 2013 that Sandiford's appeal had been denied and her conviction and death sentence upheld.<ref name=Guardian-2013-04-08/> The Court ruled the original sentence was "accurate and correct," and gave her 14 days to lodge an appeal with the Indonesian Supreme Court.<ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-22061670 |work=BBC News |title=Lindsay Sandiford loses Bali death sentence appeal |publisher=BBC |date=8 April 2013 |accessdate=8 April 2013 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130408120132/http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-22061670 |archivedate=8 April 2013 |df= }}</ref> Agus announced on 19 April that an appeal would be lodged within the next few days.<ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/worldnews/asia/indonesia/10005409/Lindsay-Sandiford-to-appeal-Bali-death-sentence.html |title=Lindsay Sandiford to appeal Bali death sentence |publisher=Telegraph Media Group |newspaper=The Daily Telegraph |date=19 April 2013 |accessdate=22 April 2013 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130422114040/http://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/worldnews/asia/indonesia/10005409/Lindsay-Sandiford-to-appeal-Bali-death-sentence.html |archivedate=22 April 2013 |df= }}</ref> On 23 April notice was given by Sandiford's lawyer to the Supreme Court that she would challenge the sentence.<ref>{{cite news|first=Neil |last=Lancefield |url=https://www.independent.co.uk/news/uk/home-news/british-grandmother-lindsay-sandiford-launching-death-sentence-challenge-at-indonesian-supreme-court-lawyers-confirm-8584231.html |title=British grandmother Lindsay Sandiford launching death sentence challenge at Indonesian Supreme Court, lawyers confirm |publisher=Independent Print Ltd |newspaper=The Independent |date=23 April 2013 |accessdate=23 April 2013}}</ref>
On 7 May 2013, Sandiford appealed against her sentence to the Indonesian Supreme Court.<ref>{{cite news|last=Dassanayake |first=Dion |url=http://www.express.co.uk/news/world/397834/Lindsay-Sandiford-launches-appeal-against-death-penalty-for-drugs-smuggling |title=Lindsay Sandiford launches appeal against death penalty for drugs smuggling |newspaper=Daily Express |publisher=Northern and Shell Media |date=7 May 2013 |accessdate=10 May 2013}}</ref> On 30 August, the Supreme Court rejected her appeal.<ref name="BBC upheld">{{cite news|title=Bali drugs case: Lindsay Sandiford loses death sentence appeal|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-23894761|accessdate=30 August 2013|newspaper=BBC|date=30 August 2013|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130831180945/http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-23894761|archivedate=31 August 2013|df=}}</ref> Sandiford is able to lodge a judicial review if new evidence is presented or if there was negligence in the case.<ref name="BBC upheld" />
Sandiford applied for a presidential pardon in December 2014. In 2015 she recruited Indonesian lawyers for an attempt to seek a retrial on her behalf.<ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.highbeam.com/doc/1P2-39867168.html |title=Death Row Drugs Gran's 60th Birthday in Prison; North Woman Faces Firing Squad Should Appeals Fail |newspaper=Sunday Sun |location=Newcastle-upon-Tyne |publisher=ncjMedia Ltd |date=24 July 2016 |accessdate=18 February 2018 |via=HighBeam Research |subscription=yes |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20180218220007/https://www.highbeam.com/doc/1P2-39867168.html |archivedate=18 February 2018 |df= }}</ref> No date had been set for her execution as of August 2017.<ref>{{cite news |last=Hill |first=Laura |url=https://www.highbeam.com/doc/1P4-1926287914.html |title=North East Gran Spends Birthday on Death Row |newspaper=Sunday Sun |location=Newcastle-upon-Tyne |publisher=ncjMedia Ltd |date=6 August 2017 |accessdate=18 February 2018 |via=HighBeam Research |subscription=yes |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20180218220007/https://www.highbeam.com/doc/1P4-1926287914.html |archivedate=18 February 2018 |df= }}</ref> In February 2018 she was still in [[Kerobokan Prison]] on Bali.<ref>{{cite news|title=Female prisoners in Bali move to new facility|url=http://www.thejakartapost.com/news/2018/02/14/female-prisoners-in-bali-move-to-new-facility.html|work=The Jakarta Post|date=14 February 2018|language=en|accessdate=18 February 2018|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20180214193958/http://www.thejakartapost.com/news/2018/02/14/female-prisoners-in-bali-move-to-new-facility.html|archivedate=14 February 2018|df=}}</ref>
===UK government legal challenge=== On the day Sandiford lodged her preliminary appeal the London-based law firm [[Leigh Day]] which is working with Reprieve on her behalf said it would seek a judicial review of the UK government's position that it does not provide funds for the legal representation of British nationals facing criminal proceedings overseas.<ref name=BBC-2013-01-28>{{cite news |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-england-gloucestershire-21228605 |work=BBC News |title=Death penalty Briton Lindsay Sandiford requests appeal |publisher=BBC |date=28 January 2013 |accessdate=28 January 2013 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130131063124/http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-england-gloucestershire-21228605 |archivedate=31 January 2013 |df= }}</ref> Reprieve believed that by not providing Sandiford, a British citizen, with financial help to cover her legal costs the government had breached its obligations towards her.<ref name=BBC-2013-01-29/> The legal challenge was heard at the High Court before [[Elizabeth Gloster|Mrs Justice Gloster]] and [[Nicola Davies (judge)|Mrs Justice Nicola Davies]] on 31 January, but the case was dismissed.<ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-21272490 |work=BBC News |title=Bali drugs: Lindsay Sandiford loses legal funding case |publisher=BBC |date=31 January 2013 |accessdate=31 January 2013 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130131185449/http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-21272490 |archivedate=31 January 2013 |df= }}</ref><ref>{{cite news |first=Jeremy |last=Armstrong |url=https://www.mirror.co.uk/news/uk-news/lindsay-sandiford-gran-on-death-row-1567489 |title=Lindsay Sandiford: Gran on death row for smuggling drugs loses legal battle with British government over appeal funding |newspaper=Daily Mirror |publisher=Trinity Mirror |date=31 January 2013 |accessdate=1 February 2013 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130131205157/http://www.mirror.co.uk/news/uk-news/lindsay-sandiford-gran-on-death-row-1567489 |archivedate=31 January 2013 |df= }}</ref> The judges ruled that Sandiford had "no reasonable prospect of success", remarks that attracted criticism from anti–death penalty campaigners.<ref name=Telegraph-2013-02-11/>
Sandiford appealed against this decision, but it was again rejected at the High Court in April 2013, by a three-judge panel, chaired by [[Master of the Rolls]] [[John Dyson, Lord Dyson|Lord Dyson]]. By then Sandiford's first line of appeal against her death sentence had been rejected, and she required £6,000 towards her legal costs for the next stage of her appeal.{{efn|The full cost of Sandiford's appeal to the Indonesian Supreme Court was £8,000. £2,000 of this had been raised at the time the case was heard on 22 April 2013.<ref name=BBC-2013-04-22/> By 1 May £10,000 had been raised.<ref name=BBC-2013-05-01/>}} In his summing up on 22 April Lord Dyson said that it was "most unfortunate" Sandiford required "relatively speaking ... [a] very small sum indeed" for her legal costs, but that this "cannot affect the principle that we have had to consider and it cannot affect our decision. It may be that other means may be found to secure the relatively small sum in the course of the next few days."<ref name=BBC-2013-04-22>{{cite news |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-22244809 |work=BBC News |title=Drug smuggler Lindsay Sandiford loses appeal for legal funds |publisher=BBC |date=22 April 2013 |accessdate=22 April 2013 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130422113011/http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-22244809 |archivedate=22 April 2013 |df= }}</ref> The judges published their reasons for rejecting the appeal on 22 May.<ref>{{cite news |first=Sophie |last=Barley |url=http://www.gazettelive.co.uk/news/teesside-news/teesside-gran-lindsay-sandifords-death-4002129 |title=Teesside gran Lindsay Sandiford's death appeal ruling "not unlawful" |publisher=Trinity Mirror |newspaper=Evening Gazette |date=22 May 2013 |accessdate=28 May 2013 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130906165714/http://www.gazettelive.co.uk/news/teesside-news/teesside-gran-lindsay-sandifords-death-4002129 |archivedate=6 September 2013 |df= }}</ref> In the written judgement, Lord Dyson said that Sandiford had argued the Foreign Secretary's position was "unlawful" but that the High Court had been "right to conclude" it was not. "As the Secretary of State concedes, it would be possible to produce a policy under which funds for legal representation were made available to British nationals in certain defined circumstances...But the question is not whether the Secretary of State could produce a different policy which many would regard as fairer and more reasonable and humane than the present policy. It is whether the policy that he has produced is irrational. I am in no doubt that the policy is not irrational. It is based on reasoning which is coherent and which is neither arbitrary nor perverse."<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.hartlepoolmail.co.uk/news/north-east/death-appeal-ruling-not-unlawful-1-5696402 |title=Death appeal ruling 'not unlawful' |publisher=Johnston Press |newspaper=Hartlepool Mail |date=23 May 2013 |accessdate=28 May 2013}}{{dead link|date=February 2017}}</ref>
In a written interview with [[BBC Radio 5 Live]] presenter [[Victoria Derbyshire]] shortly after the UK appeal was rejected, Sandiford said that the Foreign Office's stance was "tantamount to condoning the death penalty" and claimed she was receiving little support from them. "The government and FCO are doing all they can to resist me at this difficult time."<ref name=BBC-2013-05-01>{{cite news |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-22365358 |work=BBC News |title=Lindsay Sandiford accuses UK of condoning death penalty |publisher=BBC |date=1 May 2013 |accessdate=2 May 2013 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130502215200/http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-22365358 |archivedate=2 May 2013 |df= }}</ref>

{{Refimprove|date=September 2015}}
The '''Maddox Wing''' is an instrument utilized by [[ophthalmology|ophthalmologists]], [[orthoptics|orthoptists]] and [[optometry|optometrists]] in the measurement of [[strabismus]] (misalignment of the eyes; commonly referred to as a ''squint'' or ''lazy eye'' by the lay person). It is a quantitative and subjective method of measuring the size of a strabismic deviation by dissociation of the eyes brought about by two septa which are placed in such a way as to present fields to either eye separated by a diaphragm at the centre.<ref name="Davis" /> The right eye sees a red and white arrow, each of which point to a scale with numbers seen by the left eye; the red arrow points to the vertical red scale and the white arrow points to the horizontal white scale. A third arrow located to the right and below the horizontal white scale is used to measure torsion
[[File:Maddox Wing..jpg|thumb|The Maddox Wing]]
== Indications == The Maddox Wing measures the size of [[heterophoria]]s (latent deviations) and small [[heterotropia]]s (manifest deviations) at near when [[normal retinal correspondence]] (NRC) is present. It is especially helpful when patients present with symptoms of [[diplopia]] (double vision) with no apparent cause.<ref name="Davis" /> Unsuspected torsional deviations may also be revealed where there are no symptoms present. It is a quick and convenient method of measuring the size of a deviation and is generally used in association with a number of other tests before a full diagnosis is determined.
[[File:Maddox Wing.jpg|thumb|The scale card of the Maddox Wing, depicting the horizontal, vertical, torsional scales and their respective arrows.]]
== Equipment == '''The Handle:'''
The handle is retractable and is located at the base of the instrument. This is where the patient holds the apparatus.
'''The Eye Piece:'''
Located anteriorly, the eye piece is where the patient looks into.
'''The Eye-piece lens holder:'''
Mainly used to hold lens for patients who have difficulties seeing the board with their glasses
'''The Septa:'''
There are 2 septa that separates the eye piece so that the patient has two separate fields of view.
'''The Scale Card:'''
Used to measure the deviation of heterophorias, small heterotropias (with NRC) and also torsion. The scale card has the horizontal, vertical and torsional scales. The board also contains the red and white arrows. This will be further discuss throughout the video.
'''The Torsion Lever:'''
On the measuring board there is an adjustable lever which the patient subjectively aligns to measure torsion.
== Method == The Maddox Wing test is performed at near with the instrument held in reading position, slightly inferior (approximately 15° depression and 33 cm away). The room or location of the test should be brightly illuminated and the patient's optical correction (e.g. glasses, bifocals, multifocals, contact lens) is required to be worn. In the event that correction cannot be worn due to the obstruction of vision through the eye piece, lenses may be placed within the lens holder before each eye. The examiner instructs the patient to hold the Maddox Wing and identify the number that the white (vertical arrow) and red (horizontal arrow) arrows point to on their respective scales.
Example instructions and examiner questions: * "Hold the device up to your eyes and look into the eye piece as if you're reading a book" * "What number is the white arrow pointing to?" * It is important for the examiner to ask "Is it actually pointing to the number (e.g. number 4) or in between two numbers (e.g. between the numbers 3 and 5)?" This avoids possible confusion as only the odd numbers show on one side of the scale and the even figures on the other, if misinterpreted, diagnosis may be incorrect. * "What number is the red arrow pointing to?" * " I want you to lift the red torsion lever and hold it parallel to the red arrow"
== Recording == '''Example:''' # MW: cc exo 10∆ R/L 7∆ excyclo 4° ''OR'' MW: cc -10∆ R/L 7∆ excyclo 4° # MW cc eso 5∆ ө
'''Key:''' {| class="wikitable" !Symbol !Meaning/Definition |- |∆ |[[Dioptre|Prism Dioptres]] (i.e. measurement of deviation) |- |° |Degrees (i.e. measurement of deviation) |- | - |Exo-deviation |- | + |Eso-deviation |- |ө |No Vertical Deviation |- |ɸ |No Horizontal Deviation |- |cc |With optical correction |- |sc |Without optical correction |}
== Interpretation == With the maddox wing, you cannot differentiate between a manifest deviation or latent deviation. The white arrow on the white [[X-axis|X-Axis]] measures for horizontal deviations in which, odd numbers represent eso deviations and even numbers represents exo deviations. The red arrow on the red [[Y-axis|Y-Axis]] measures for vertical deviations; odd numbers represent right hyper deviations and even numbers represents left hyper deviations. In the absence of a deviated eye, both red and white arrows point to zero, indicating that there is no deviation present. The presence of torsion is determined subjectively; the patient is instructed to take hold of the torsion lever and make it straight.
== Advantages == * Time efficient method of measuring strabismus * Measures horizontal, vertical and torsional deviations * Hand held instrument * Not a difficult skill to learn * Can be used on children
== Disadvantages == * Contraindicated where [[Retinal correspondence|abnormal retinal correspondence (ARC)]] or suppression are present * The associative nature of the test may cause irregularities in measurements * Does not differentiate between latent and manifest strabismus * Septa is easily bent, may lead to incorrect results as one eye sees both arrows and numbers * Cannot be performed in the distance
== Considerations == * Time must be allowed for dissociation of the eyes to take place * Numbers and arrows should be seen clearly. Relaxation of accommodation can result in an increase in exophoria and a decrease in esophoria, leading to an inaccurate result * The examiner should check the function of the Maddox Wing Instrument before use; the septa can be easily bent, leading to the septa not covering the intended view. When that happens one eye can see both arrows and numbers which gives inaccurate results.
== References == {{reflist|refs= <ref name=Davis>{{cite book|last1=Davis|first1=Alec M. Ansons, Helen|title=Diagnosis and management of ocular motility disorders|date=2014|publisher=Wiley-Blackwell|location=Chicester|isbn=9781405193061|edition=Fourth}}</ref> }} <!-- July 2018 - these 3 cites were originally tagged as <ref> but not used w/in article --> * {{cite book|title=Clinical Orthoptics|date=2012|publisher=John Wiley & Sons|location=Hoboken|isbn=9781118341599|pages=104|edition=3rd}} * {{cite journal|last1=Pointer|first1=Jonathan S.|title=An enhancement to the Maddox Wing test for the reliable measurement of horizontal heterophoria|journal=Ophthalmic and Physiological Optics|date=September 2005|volume=25|issue=5|pages=446–451|doi=10.1111/j.1475-1313.2005.00303.x}} * {{cite book|last1=Trevor-Roper|first1=P.D.|last2=Curran|first2=Peter V.|title=The eye and its disorders.|date=1984|publisher=Blackwell Scientific Publications ; St. Louis, Mo. : Distributors, USA, Blackwell Mosby|location=Oxford ; Boston|isbn=0-632-01003-7|pages=249–250|edition=2nd}}

{{about|the meal component|the Bee Gees album|Main Course}} {{meals}}
The '''main course''' is the featured or primary dish in a [[meal]] consisting of several courses. It usually follows the [[entrée]] ("entry") course.
==Usage== In the United States and Canada (except [[Quebec]]), the main course is traditionally called an "'''entrée'''".<ref name="Oxford Dictionaries">{{cite web|url=http://oxforddictionaries.com/definition/entr%C3%A9e|title=Oxford Dictionaries|publisher=|accessdate=12 September 2017}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.macmillandictionary.com/dictionary/british/entree|title=entrée (noun) definition and synonyms - Macmillan Dictionary|website=www.macmillandictionary.com|accessdate=12 September 2017}}</ref><ref>''cf.'' [http://dictionary.cambridge.org/dictionary/british/entree_1 Cambridge]</ref><ref name="etiquette">{{cite book | url=https://books.google.com/books?id=9TL8PFlYRkUC&lpg=PA99&dq=entree%20main%20course&pg=PA99#v=onepage&q=entree%20main%20course&f=false | title=Commonsense Etiquette: A Guide to Gracious, Simple Manners for the Twenty-First Century | year=1999 | author=Stewart, Marjabelle Young and Elizabeth Lawrence | publisher=St. Martin's Press | page=99}}</ref> English-speaking Québécois follow the modern French use of the term entrée to refer to a [[Entrée|dish served before the main course]].
According to linguist Dan Jurafsky, North American usage ("entrée") retains the original French meaning of a substantial meat course.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.pri.org/stories/2014-09-22/sure-you-are-what-you-eatbut-youre-also-how-you-translate-menu|title=You are what you eat — and how you translate the menu|publisher=|accessdate=12 September 2017}}</ref>
[[Image:Sirloin steak.JPG|thumb|left|200px|A [[sirloin steak]] dinner. This may be the main course of a meal.]]
==Serving== The main dish is usually the heaviest, heartiest, and most complex or substantial dish on a menu. The main ingredient is usually [[meat]], [[Fish (food)|fish]] or another protein source. It is most often preceded by an [[Hors d'œuvre|appetizer]], [[soup]] or [[salad]], and followed by a [[dessert]]. For those reasons the main course is sometimes referred to as the "meat course".
In formal dining, a well-planned main course can function as a sort of gastronomic apex or climax. In such a scheme, the preceding courses are designed to prepare for and lead up to the main course in such a way that the main course is anticipated and, when the scheme is successful, increased in its ability to satisfy and delight the diner. The courses following the main course then calm the [[palate]] and the [[stomach]], acting as a sort of [[dénouement]] or anticlimax.
